case_name: Seth Badri Prasad & Ors. v. Nagar Mal & Ors.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 125 of 1955 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 125 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated November 20, 1951, of the Court of Judicial Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, in Civil First Appeal No. 47 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated November 20, 1951, of the former Court of Judicial Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, in Civil First Appeal No. 47 of 1951, arising out of the judgment and decree dated June 4, 1951, of the Court of Additional District Judge, Umaria, in Civil Original Suit No. 17/19/17 of 1950.

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and decree dated June 4, 1951, of the Court of Additional District Judge, Umaria, in Civil Original Suit No. 17/19/17 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated November 20, 1951, of the former Court of Judicial Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, in Civil First Appeal No. 47 of 1951, arising out of the judgment and decree dated June 4, 1951, of the Court of Additional District Judge, Umaria, in Civil Original Suit No. 17/19/17 of 1950.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on December 9, 1958 by K. DAS, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. December 9. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the erstwhile Judicial Commissioner of Vindhya Pradesh, which is number part of the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Preliminary objection by respondent number 1, Nagar Mal, that suit was not maintainable by reason of s. 4 of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of respondent number 1, Nagar Mal, who was defendant number 1 in the suit, a preliminary objection has been taken to the effect that the suit was number maintainable by reason of the provisions of s. 4 of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935, and the appeal filed by the plaintiffs must, therefore, be dismissed.

facts.text: Preliminary objection not taken in lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: As this preliminary objection was number taken in any of the two companyrts below, learned companynsel for the appellants wanted time to companysider the point.

facts.text: Appeal hearing adjourned on October 28, 1958 for a month.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, on October 28, 1958, we adjourned the hearing of the appeal for about a month. The appeal was then heard on November 27, 1958.

facts.text: Appeal heard on November 27, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was then heard on November 27, 1958. As we are of the opinion that the preliminary objection must succeed, it is necessary to state the facts only in so far as they have a bearing on it.

facts.text: Cloth control came into force in Rewa State.

anchor.surface_text: When cloth companytrol came into force in Rewa State, the cloth dealers of Budhar a town in that State, formed themselves into an Association to companylect the quota of cloth to be allotted to them and sell it on profit wholesale and retail.

facts.text: Cloth dealers of Budhar formed an Association of 25 members.

anchor.surface_text: the cloth dealers of Budhar a town in that State, formed themselves into an Association to companylect the quota of cloth to be allotted to them and sell it on profit wholesale and retail. The, Association at Budhar companysisted of 25 members who made companytributions to the initial capital of the association which was one lac of rupees.

facts.text: Association had initial capital of one lac of rupees from members' contributions.

anchor.surface_text: The, Association at Budhar companysisted of 25 members who made companytributions to the initial capital of the association which was one lac of rupees. No formal Articles of Association were written number Se was it registered.

facts.text: No formal Articles of Association written nor registered.

anchor.surface_text: No formal Articles of Association were written number Se was it registered. The Association functioned through a President and a pioneer worker they kept accounts and distributed the profits.

facts.text: Nagar Mal was President from January 1946 to June 26, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent number 1, Nagar Mal, was the President of the said Association from January 1946 to June 26, 1946. Before that, Seth Badri Prasad, one of the plaintiffs appellants before us, was the President.

facts.text: Seth Badri Prasad was President before Nagar Mal.

anchor.surface_text: Before that, Seth Badri Prasad, one of the plaintiffs appellants before us, was the President. Nagar Mal ceased to be President after June 26, 1946, and Seth Badri Prasad again became President.

facts.text: Association worked till February 1948 then cloth decontrolled.

anchor.surface_text: The Association worked till Febr- uary 1948 then cloth was decontrolled and the work of the Association came to an end.

facts.text: On June 25, 1949, thirteen members out of twenty-five brought a suit.

anchor.surface_text: On June 25, 1949, thirteen members of the Association out of the twenty-five brought a suit, and in the plaint they alleged that respondent number 1, who was President of the Association, from January 1946 to June 1946, had given an account of income and expenditure for the months of January, February and March, 1946, but had given numberaccounts for the months of April, May and June, 1946.

facts.text: Plaintiffs alleged Nagar Mal gave accounts for Jan, Feb, Mar 1946 but not Apr, May, Jun 1946.

anchor.surface_text: and in the plaint they alleged that respondent number 1, who was President of the Association, from January 1946 to June 1946, had given an account of income and expenditure for the months of January, February and March, 1946, but had given numberaccounts for the months of April, May and June, 1946.

facts.text: Suit prayed for accounts from April 1946 to June 26, 1946, payment of dues with interest at annas 12 per cent per month.

anchor.surface_text: They, therefore, prayed -  a that defendant number 1  Nagar Mal  be ordered to give the accounts of the Cloth Association, Budhar, from the beginning of the month of April 1946 to June 26, 1946  b that defendant number 1 be ordered to pay the amount, whatever is found due to the plaintiffs on account being done, along with interest at the rate of annas 12 per cent. per month and  c that interest for the period of the suit and till the realisation of the dues be allowed.

facts.text: Other eleven members joined as proforma defendants, some later as plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: Besides Nagar Mal the other eleven businessmen, who were members of the Association, were joined as proforma defendants, some of whom later filed an application to be joined as plaintiffs.

facts.text: Real dispute related to sale of Gwalior consignment.

anchor.surface_text: Though the plaint did number mention any particular transaction of the Association during the period when Nagar Mal was its President, the judgments of the companyrts below show that the real dispute between the parties related to the sale of cloth of a companysignment known as the Gwalior companysignment.

facts.text: In April 1946, consignment of 666 bales of cloth came from Gwalior.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in April 1946 a companysignment of 666 bales of cloth had companye from Gwalior and an order was passed by the Cloth Control Officer that the companysignment would be allotted to Nagar Mal who would give the Association an option of taking over the companysignment if the Association did number exercise the option, the companysignment would be taken over by Nagar Mal.

facts.text: Cloth Control Officer ordered 390 bales allotted to Association, Nagar Mal gave benefit of sales of 106 bales, dispute on remaining 284 bales.

anchor.surface_text: It is enough if we say that ultimately there was an order to the effect that only 390 bales should be allotted to the Association out of which Nagar Mal had given the Association benefit of the sales of 106 bales, and the dispute related to the share of profits made on the remaining 284 bales.

facts.text: Nagar Mal's main defence: none of members entitled to share in profits on 284 bales.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1, Nagar Mal, raised various points by way of defence, his main defence being that numbere of the members of the Association were entitled to any share in the profits on the sales of 284 bales of Gwalior cloth.

facts.text: Additional District Judge passed preliminary decree directing accounts from April 1, 1946 to June 26, 1946, account of 390-106 bales per capital shares.

anchor.surface_text: The learned District Judge, who dealt with the suit in the first instance, passed a preliminary decree in favour of the plaintiff-appellants. The decree directed Nagar Mal to render accounts of the Cloth Association at Budhar from April 1, 1946 to June 26, 1946, and it further directed that leaving out 106 bales of Gwalior cloth which Nagar Mal gave to the Association, an account should be rendered of the rest of the 390 bales and the profits on the sale thereof shall be according to the capital shares of the members of the Association.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner reversed District Judge, held members not entitled to 284 bales profits, suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Nagar Mal preferred an appeal to the learned Judicial Commissioner of Vindhya Pradesh, who reversed the finding of the learned District Judge and came to the companyclusion that the other members of the Association were number entitled to participate in the profits made on the sale of 284 bales of the Gwalior cloth and inasmuch as Nagar Mal had rendered accounts with regard to all other transactions, the suit for accounts must fail. He accordingly allowed the appeal and dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Counsel for appellants conceded s.4(2) Rewa State Companies Act 1935 in force when Association formed and till 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sardar Bahadur, who has appeared on behalf of the appellants and who took time to companysider the point, has number companyceded before us that the aforesaid provision was in force in the Rewa State at the relevant time when the Association was formed at Budhar and he, has further companyceded that the said provision was in force till the Indian Companies Act came into force in the said area in 1950.

facts.text: Association consisted of more than 20 persons, not registered under Rewa State Companies Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, more than twenty persons formed the Association in question and it is number disputed that it was formed in companytravention of s. 4 2  of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935.

facts.text: Court held preliminary objection succeeds, Association illegal, no suit for accounts.

anchor.surface_text: As we are of the opinion that the preliminary objection must succeed, it is necessary to state the facts only in so far as they have a bearing on it.

sub-s. (2) of s. 4 which is in these terms- 4 (2 ). No companypany, association or partnership, companysisting of more than twenty persons shall be formed for the purpose of carrying on any other, business that has for its object the acquisition of gain by the companypany, association or partnership, or by the individual members thereof, unless it is registered as a companypany under this Act, or is formed in pursuance of a Charter from the Durbar.

concepts.interpretation: the Cloth Association at Budhar was not a legal Association, because it was formed for the purpose of carrying on a business which had for its object the acquisition of gain by the individual members thereof and further because it was not registered as a Company under the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935 nor was it formed in pursuance of a charter from the Durbar

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: a right to bring a suit for accounts of the Association which was dissolved in February 1948. We proceed number to companysider these companytentions

concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibits formation of association or partnership of more than 20 persons for gain-oriented business unless registered or chartered

anchor.surface_text: The preliminary point taken before us is founded on the provisions of s. 4 of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935. Sub-section (1) of s. 4 relates to banking business. We are concerned with sub-s. (2) of s. 4

on the analogy of s. 69 3 a of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, it should be held that the appellants had a right to bring a suit for accounts of the Association which was dissolved in February 1948.

concepts.interpretation: an unregistered firm is not illegal there is no direct compulsion that a partnership firm must be registered, though the disabilities consequent on non-registration may be extremely inconvenient. Moreover, the suit before us was not one for accounts of a dissolved firm, but for accounts of an illegal association

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: l laws be infringed with impunity, but, what is worse, their very infringement would become a ground for obtaining relief from those whose business it

anchor.surface_text: The most important consequence, however, of illegality in a contract of partnership is that the members of the partnership have no remedy against each other for contribution or apportionment in respect of the partnership dealings and transactions. However ungracious and morally reprehensible it may be...

concepts.interpretation: When the association is itself illegal, a court cannot assist the plaintiffs in getting accounts made so that they may have their full share of the profits made by the illegal association

The question is a pure question of law and does not require the investigation of any facts. ... The enactment is prohibitory. It is not confined to affording a party a protection...

issues.text: Whether the suit is maintainable or whether the Cloth Association at Budhar was a legal association given that it consisted of more than twenty persons formed for business with object of acquisition of gain by members, unregistered under Rewa State Companies Act, 1935 or without charter from Durbar, such that members have no remedy for accounts

anchor.surface_text: The preliminary point taken before us is founded on the provisions of s. 4 of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935. Sub-section (1) of s. 4 relates to banking business. We are concerned with sub-s. (2) of s. 4 which is in these terms- 4 (2 ). No companypany, association or partnership, companysisting of more than twenty persons shall be formed for the purpose of carrying on any other, business that has for its object the acquisition of gain by the companypany, association or partnership, or by the individual members thereof, unless it is registered as a companypany under this Act, or is formed in pursuance of a Charter from the Durbar. Mr. Sardar Bahadur, who has appeared on behalf of the appellants and who took time to companysider the point, has number companyceded before us that the aforesaid provision was in force in the Rewa State at the relevant time when the Association was formed at Budhar and he, has further companyceded that the said provision was in force till the Indian Companies Act came into force in the said area in 1950. We must, therefore, decide the preliminary point on the basis of the provision in s. 4 (2) of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935. Now, the preliminary point taken on behalf of respondent number1 is this. It is companytended that by reason of s. 4 (2) aforesaid, the Cloth Association at Budhar was number a legal Association, because it was formed for the purpose of carrying on a business which had for its object the acquisition of gain by the individual members thereof and further because it was number registered as a Company under the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935 number was it formed in pursuance of a charter from the Durbar.

issues.text: Whether the preliminary objection based on s. 4(2) of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935 can be raised at this late appellate stage though not raised in courts below

anchor.surface_text: The first companytention that respondent number 1 should number be allowed to raise an objection of the kind which he has number raised at this late stage can be disposed of very easily. The objection taken rests on the provisions of a public statute which numbercourt can exclude from its companysideration. The question is a pure question of law and does number require the investigation of any facts. Admittedly, more than twenty persons formed the Association in question and it is number disputed that it was formed in companytravention of s. 4 (2) of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935.

issues.text: Whether, even if the Association contravened s. 4(2) of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935, its purpose was not illegal such that suit for recovery of contributions and accounts was maintainable

anchor.surface_text: On his second companytention learned companynsel for the appellants has relied on U. Sein Po v. U. Phyu  2 . That was a case in which three members of an association formed for carrying on a rice business claimed a decree  1  declaring the respective shares of the subscribers to that association and directing that the plaintiffs be repaid their shares after reconverting the property of the association into cash and after payment of all debts and liabilities. The association, it was found, companysisted of twenty-seven members it was number registered and its formation was in companytravention of sub-s.  (2) of s. 4 of the Indian Companies Act.

issues.text: Whether, on the analogy of s. 69(3)(a) of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, the appellants had a right to bring a suit for accounts of the Association dissolved in February 1948

anchor.surface_text: on the analogy of s. 69 3 a of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, it should be held that the appellants had a right to bring a suit for accounts of the Association which was dissolved in February 1948.... Moreover, the suit before us was not one for accounts of a dissolved firm, but for accounts of an illegal association

arguments.claim: Suit not maintainable because Cloth Association illegal under s.4(2) Rewa State Companies Act as >20 members for business acquiring gain, unregistered, no charter; members have no remedy for accounts due to illegality

anchor.surface_text: Now, the preliminary point taken on behalf of respondent number1 is this. It is contended that by reason of s. 4 (2) aforesaid, the Cloth Association at Budhar was not a legal Association, because it was formed for the purpose of carrying on a business which had for its object the acquisition of gain by the individual members thereof and further because it was not registered as a Company under the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935 nor was it formed in pursuance of a charter from the Durbar. It has been contended before us on behalf of respondent number1 that by reason of the illegality in the contract of partnership the members of the partnership have no remedy against each other for contribution or apportionment in respect of the partnership dealings and transactions. Therefore, no suit for accounts lay at the instance of the plaintiffs-appellants, who were also members of the said illegal Association.

arguments.claim: Even if Association contravened s.4(2), purpose not illegal; suit maintainable for recovery of contributions and accounts

anchor.surface_text: secondly, he has contended that even though the Association was in contravention of s. 4 (2) of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935, the purpose of the Association was not illegal and a suit was maintainable for recovery of the contributions made by the appellants and also for accounts

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tion the provisions of a public statute. In our view, the same principle applies in the present case and s. 4 2  of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935

arguments.court_reasoning: distinguishes U Sein Po v U Phyu as different relief (return subscriptions vs enforce accounts); cites Lindley on Partnership that no remedy for illegal partnership transactions

court_response_anchor.surface_text: l laws be infringed with impunity, but, what is worse, their very infringement would become a ground for obtaining relief from those whose business it

arguments.court_reasoning: unregistered firm not illegal unlike here; suit not for dissolved firm but illegal association accounts

arguments.claim: Cloth Association illegal under s.4(2) Rewa Act: >20 persons, business for gain by members, unregistered, no charter

anchor.surface_text: The preliminary point taken before us is founded on the provisions of s. 4 of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935... the Cloth Association at Budhar was not a legal Association, because it was formed for the purpose of carrying on a business which had for its object the acquisition of gain by the individual members thereof and further because it was not registered as a Company under the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935 nor was it formed in pursuance of a charter from the Durbar.

arguments.claim: Late-stage objection on prohibitory public statute admissible as pure question of law

anchor.surface_text: The first contention that respondent number 1 should not be allowed to raise an objection of the kind which he has not raised at this late stage can be disposed of very easily. The objection taken rests on the provisions of a public statute which no court can exclude from its consideration. The question is a pure question of law and does not require the investigation of any facts.

arguments.claim: Members of illegal partnership/association have no court remedy for accounts or share of profits

anchor.surface_text: When the association is itself illegal, a court cannot assist the plaintiffs in getting accounts made so that they may have their full share of the profits made by the illegal association.

arguments.claim: U Sein Po v U Phyu not applicable as relief there was return of subscriptions to prevent continuance of illegality, not enforcement of accounts

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the decision aforesaid, be it correct or otherwise, is of any help to the appellants in the present case. The appellants herein have not asked for a return or refund of their subscriptions on the contrary, they have asked for a rendition of accounts in enforcement of an illegal contract of partnership.

holdings.text: The Cloth Association at Budhar was not a legal Association by reason of s. 4(2) of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935, as it consisted of more than 20 persons formed for business acquiring gain by members, unregistered and without charter; therefore no suit for accounts lies between members

anchor.surface_text: Now, the preliminary point taken on behalf of respondent number1 is this. It is contended that by reason of s. 4 (2) aforesaid, the Cloth Association at Budhar was not a legal Association, because it was formed for the purpose of carrying on a business which had for its object the acquisition of gain by the individual members thereof and further because it was not registered as a Company under the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935 nor was it formed in pursuance of a charter from the Durbar. It has been contended before us on behalf of respondent number1 that by reason of the illegality in the contract of partnership the members of the partnership have no remedy against each other for contribution or apportionment in respect of the partnership dealings and transactions. Therefore, no suit for accounts lay at the instance of the plaintiffs-appellants, who were also members of the said illegal Association. We consider that this contention is sound and must be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Association admitted to have 25 members contributing capital for cloth trading profits, no registration or charter; applies s.4(2) directly and illegal partnership doctrine barring inter-member remedies

holdings.text: Preliminary objection under prohibitory public statute s.4(2) Rewa State Companies Act can be raised at appellate stage despite not raised below, as pure question of law

anchor.surface_text: The first contention that respondent number 1 should not be allowed to raise an objection of the kind which he has not raised at this late stage can be disposed of very easily. The objection taken rests on the provisions of a public statute which no court can exclude from its consideration. The question is a pure question of law and does not require the investigation of any facts. Admittedly, more than twenty persons formed the Association in question and it is not disputed that it was formed in contravention of s. 4 (2) of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935. [...] s. 4 (2) of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935, being prohibitory in nature cannot be excluded from consideration even though the bar of that provision has been raised at this late stage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on precedents Surajmull v Triton and Shiba Prasad v Srish Chandra holding courts cannot ignore prohibitory statutes; no facts needed, admitted contravention

holdings.text: Even if Association contravened s.4(2), suit for accounts enforces illegal contract, not maintainable unlike claim for return of subscriptions to end illegality

anchor.surface_text: On his second contention learned counsel for the appellants has relied on U. Sein Po v. U. Phyu. [...] When the association is itself illegal, a court cannot assist the plaintiffs in getting accounts made so that they may have their full share of the profits made by the illegal association.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes U Sein Po (return subscriptions to prevent continuance of illegality) from present enforcement of accounts implying recognition of illegal association; cites Lindley on Partnership no remedy for illegal partnership transactions

holdings.text: Analogy to s.69(3)(a) Indian Partnership Act does not apply as unregistered firm not illegal unlike this association, and suit is for accounts of illegal association not dissolved firm

anchor.surface_text: thirdly, he has contended that on the analogy of s. 69 (3 ) (a ) of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, it should be held that the appellants had a right to bring a suit for accounts of the Association which was dissolved in February 1948. [...] under the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, an unregistered firm is not illegal there is no direct compulsion that a partnership firm must be registered [...] Moreover, the suit before us was not one for accounts of a dissolved firm, but for accounts of an illegal association [...] the analogy does not really apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unregistered partnerships lack registration disabilities but not illegal per se; here association illegal ab initio under Companies Act; relief sought enforces illegality not dissolution accounts

precedents.citation: Surajmull Nargoremull v. Triton Insurance Company Ltd.  1  1924  L.R. 52 I.A. 126, 128

anchor.surface_text: A similar question arose for companysideration in Surajmull Nargoremull v. Triton Insurance Company Ltd.  1 . In that case sub-s.  1  of s. 7 of the Indian Stamp Act  11 of 1899  was pleaded as a bar before their Lordships of the Privy Council, the section number having been pleaded earlier and having passed unnoticed in the judgments of the companyrts below. At p. 128 of the report Lord Sumner said,, The suggestion may be at once dismissed that it is too late number to raise the section as an answer to the claim. No companyrt can enforce as valid that which companypetent enactments have declared shall number be valid, number is obedience to such an enactment a thing from which a companyrt can be dispensed by the companysent of the parties, or by a failure to plead or to argue the  1  1924  L.R. 52 I.A. 126, 128. point at the outset Nixon v. Alibion Marine Insurance Co.,  1867  L. R. 2 Ex. 338. The enactment is prohibitory. It is number companyfined to affording a party a protection, of which he may avail himself or number as he pleases .

precedents.case_name: Surajmull Nargoremull v Triton Insurance Company Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: A point based on a prohibitory provision of a public statute can be raised at any stage, even if not raised in lower courts, as no court can exclude it from consideration
precedents.cited_holding: No court can enforce as valid that which competent enactments have declared shall not be valid

precedents.citation: Nixon v. Alibion Marine Insurance Co.,  1867  L. R. 2 Ex. 338

anchor.surface_text: point at the outset Nixon v. Alibion Marine Insurance Co.,  1867  L. R. 2 Ex. 338. The enactment is prohibitory. It is number companyfined to affording a party a protection, of which he may avail himself or number as he pleases . In Sri Sri Shiba Prasad Singh v. Maharaja Srish Chandra Nandi  1 , the provisions of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act were overlooked by the High Court the section was only mentioned in passing by the Subordinate Judge and it appears that the bar of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act was number argued or only faintly argued before the Subordinate Judge or in the High Court.

precedents.case_name: Nixon v Albion Marine Insurance Co
precedents.cited_proposition: Authority supporting that prohibitory enactments cannot be waived or ignored by courts

precedents.citation: Sri Sri Shiba Prasad Singh v. Maharaja Srish Chandra Nandi  1   1949  L.R. 76 I.A. 244

anchor.surface_text: In Sri Sri Shiba Prasad Singh v. Maharaja Srish Chandra Nandi  1 , the provisions of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act were overlooked by the High Court the section was only mentioned in passing by the Subordinate Judge and it appears that the bar of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act was number argued or only faintly argued before the Subordinate Judge or in the High Court. In these circumstances, their Lordships of the Privy Council held that they were unable to exclude from their companysideration the provisions of a public statute.

precedents.case_name: Sri Sri Shiba Prasad Singh v Maharaja Srish Chandra Nandi
precedents.cited_proposition: Provisions of a public statute cannot be excluded from consideration even if not argued below

precedents.citation: U. Sein Po v. U. Phyu  2   1929  I.L.R. 7 Ran. 540

anchor.surface_text: On his second contention learned counsel for the appellants has relied on U. Sein Po v. U. Phyu  2 . That was a case in which three members of an association formed for carrying on a rice business claimed a decree  1  declaring the respective shares of the subscribers to that association and directing that the plaintiffs be repaid their shares after reconverting the property of the association into cash and after payment of all debts and liabilities. The association, it was found, consisted of twenty-seven members it was not registered and its formation was in contravention of sub-s.  2  of s. 4 of the Indian Companies Act.

precedents.case_name: U Sein Po v U Phyu
precedents.cited_proposition: Members of illegal unregistered association can claim return of subscriptions and reconversion of assets

anchor.surface_text: and Butt v. Monteaux  4 , and rested their decision on the following passage of Lindley on Partnership ...  3   1855  1 K. J. 491 69 E.R. 552.  4   1854  1 K. J. 98 69 E.R. 345. Although, therefore, the subscribers to an illegal company have no a right to an account of the dealings and transactions of the company and of the profits made thereby, they have a right to have their subscriptions returned and the necessary account taken and even though the moneys subscribed have been laid out in the purchase of land and other things for the purpose of the company the subscribers are entitled to have that land and those things reconverted into money,

precedents.cited_proposition: Referenced in U Sein Po for allowing recovery in illegal company

anchor.surface_text: If money is paid by A to B to be applied by him for some illegal purpose, it is competent-for A to require B to hand back the money if B has not already parted with it and the illegal purpose has not been carried out see Greenberg v. Cooperstein  1 . The case before us stands on a different footing. It is a claim by some members of an illegal association against another member on the footing that the association should be treated as legal in order to give rise to a liability to render accounts in respect of the transac- tions of the association.

precedents.cited_proposition: Money paid for illegal purpose can be recovered back if purpose not carried out

precedents.citation: Senaji Kapurchand v. Pannaji Devichand 2   A.I.R. 1930 P.C. 300

anchor.surface_text: Where a plaintiff comes to court on allegations which on the face of them show that the contract of partnership on which he sues is illegal, the only course for the courts to pursue is to say that he is not entitled to any relief on the allegations made as the courts cannot adjudicate in respect of contracts which the law declares to be illegal  Senaji Kapurchand v. Pannaji Devichand 2  . The same view, which we

precedents.cited_proposition: Courts will not grant relief on a contract shown to be illegal on the face of the plaint
precedents.cited_holding: the only course for the courts to pursue is to say that he is not entitled to any relief

anchor.surface_text: The same view, which we  1  1926 1 Ch. 657. A.I.R. 1930 P.C. 300. think is correct, was expressed in Kumaraswami v. Chinnathambi  1 . As to the last contention of learned counsel for the appellants, based on the analogy of s. 69 3  a  of the Partnership Act, it is enough to point out that under the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, an unregistered firm is not illegal there is no direct compulsion that a partnership firm must be registered, though the disabilities consequent on non-registration may be extremely inconvenient.

precedents.cited_proposition: Same view as Senaji on illegality barring relief

outcome.relief_summary: Preliminary objection upheld; suit held not maintainable as the Cloth Association was illegal under s. 4(2) of Rewa State Companies Act, 1935, being an unregistered association of more than 20 persons for business with object of gain; appeal dismissed

anchor.surface_text: Now, the preliminary point taken on behalf of respondent number1 is this. It is contended that by reason of s. 4 (2) aforesaid, the Cloth Association at Budhar was not a legal Association, because it was formed for the purpose of carrying on a business which had for its object the acquisition of gain by the individual members thereof and further because it was not registered as a Company under the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935 nor was it formed in pursuance of a charter from the Durbar. It has been contended before us on behalf of respondent number1 that by reason of the illegality in the contract of partnership the members of the partnership have no remedy against each other for contribution or apportionment in respect of the partnership dealings and transactions. Therefore, no suit for accounts lay at the instance of the plaintiffs-appellants, who were also members of the said illegal Association. We consider that this contention is sound and must be upheld.

As this preliminary objection was number taken in any of the two companyrts below, learned companynsel for the appellants wanted time to companysider the point. Accordingly, on October 28, 1958, we adjourned the hearing of the appeal for about a month. The appeal was then heard on November 27, 1958. As we are of the opinion that the preliminary objection must succeed, it is necessary to state the facts only in so far as they have a bearing on it.

The first contention that respondent number 1 should not be allowed to raise an objection of the kind which he has not raised at this late stage can be disposed of very easily. The objection taken rests on the provisions of a public statute which no court can exclude from its consideration. The question is a pure question of law and does not require the investigation of any facts. Admittedly, more than twenty persons formed the Association in question and it is not disputed that it was formed in contravention of s. 4 (2) of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935. [...] s. 4 (2) of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935, being prohibitory in nature cannot be excluded from consideration even though the bar of that provision has been raised at this late stage.

As this preliminary objection was number taken in any of the two companyrts below, learned companynsel for the appellants wanted time to companysider the point. Accordingly, on October 28, 1958, we adjourned the hearing of the appeal for about a month. The appeal was then heard on November 27, 1958. As we are of the opinion that the preliminary objection must succeed, it is necessary to state the facts only in so far as they have a bearing on it.

As this preliminary objection was number taken in any of the two companyrts below, learned companynsel for the appellants wanted time to companysider the point. anchor.surface_text: thirdly, he has contended that on the analogy of s. 69 (3 ) (a ) of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, it should be held that the appellants had a right to bring a suit for accounts of the Association which was dissolved in February 1948. [...] under the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, an unregistered firm is not illegal there is no direct compulsion that a partnership firm must be registered [...] Moreover, the suit before us was not one for accounts of a dissolved firm, but for accounts of an illegal association [...] the analogy does not really apply.

As this preliminary objection was number taken in any of the two companyrts below, learned companynsel for the appellants wanted time to companysider the point. Accordingly, on October 28, 1958, we adjourned the hearing of the appeal for about a month. The appeal was then heard on November 27, 1958. As we are of the opinion that the preliminary objection must succeed, it is necessary to state the facts only in so far as they have a bearing on it.
